title: The nature and variety of organisms
content:
Revision note for Edexcel IGCSE Biology. 
Discussing kingdoms of organisms and characteristics of them. 


Characteristics of living organisms:
movement
action by an organism causing a change of position or place 
movement from place to place: locomotion
plants cannot move from place to place but change their orientation.


respiration
Chemical reaction in all organisms
Energy is released from glucose as ATP
presence of oxygen: aerobic respiration
absence of oxygen: anaerobic respiration
releasing carbon dioxide & water
$ glucose + oxygen ; -! >  carbon dioxide + water $


sensitivity
detect and respond to stimuli in the surroundings 
increase the chances of survival 
animals:
nervous system:
receptors 
neurones
effectors 
use electrical impulses


endocrine system
hormones
use chemical messengers  
travel in the blood




plants:
controlled by chemicals
much slower
geotropism:
gravity 
e.g. root - positively geotropism


phototropism:
light 
e.g. leaf - positively phototropism






control 
homeostasis 
control internal environment in order to keep conditions within required limits 
human:
body optimum temperature: 37°C
sweating 
vasodilation 
glucoregulation(blood glucose level)
osmoregulation(water level)


plants:
transpiration
water evaporates from stomata to loss heat 
water is taken up from soil through roots






growth
permanent increase in size 
animals
zygote -> adult 
change in proportion or shape


plants
grow larger in the whole life
new shoots, leaves, branches




reproduction:
production of more of the same kind of organism 
survival of species 
sexual reproduction:
gametes fuse together 
in humans: sperm + egg 
in plants: pollen grains + ovule




asexual reproduction: 
e.g. mitosis 
only one parent -> clone 
DNA of offspring is identical to parental DNA 
plants + single-celled organisms(bacteria, amoeba)
in plants: tubers, buddings, runners




excretion
removal of toxic materials and substances from organism
metabolic reaction: chemical reactions that take place inside living cells 
some of metabolic reaction waste is toxic
animal excretion waste:
carbon dioxide - respiration 
water - respiration and others
urea(contain nitrogen) - break down of protein


plants excretion waste:
oxygen - photosynthesis
carbon dioxide - respiration 
water - respiration and other




nutrition 
obtain food for energy. 
Plants(autotrophic): photosynthesis.
animals(heterotrophic): digest food from a range of different sources.

-Autotroph make their own food-Heterotroph get food from a range of food sources






-Eukaryotic organisms:Basics
five kingdoms of eukaryotes:
animals 
plants 
fungi 
protoctists 
Bacteria


features:
multicellular or unicellular 
contain a nucleus with distinct membranes in each cell


standard animal cells:




organelle
function



nucleus
-contain genetic material(DNA)  -controls the activities of the cell(by DNA)


cytoplasm
-gel-like substances -consist of water and dissolved solutes-support internal cell structures-site of many chemical reactions (e.g. anaerobic respiration)-contains enzymes which control these reactions


cell membrane
-separating the inside of cells from outside-controls enter and leave of substances to the cell


ribosome
-found in the cytoplasm -site of protein synthesis


mitochondria
-site of aerobic respiration-release energy to fuel cellular process-cells with higher rate of metabolism reactions have higher number of mitochondria



plant cells’ specific organelles:




organelle
function



cell wall
-made by cellulose (glucose polymer)-extra support to the cell; defining shape


chloroplast
-contain chlorophyll(green) to absorb light energy-contain enzymes needed for photosynthesis


permanent vacuole
-contain cell sap - solution of sugar and salts (juice) -store certain materials-support the shape of the cell


Animals
multicellular 
cells contain nuclei with distinct membranes
no cellulose cell walls 
no chloroplast(photosynthesis)
heterotrophic
usually have nervous coordination 
can move from place to place 
store carbohydrates as glycogen

Plants
multicellular 
cells contain nuclei with distinct membranes
cells contain cell walls (made by cellulose)
contain chloroplasts (photosynthesis)
autotrophic (feed by photosynthesis)
store carbohydrates as starch or sucrose 
no nervous coordination

Fungi
usually multicellular; some are unicellular(e.g.yeast)
multicellular fungi are made up of hyphae containing many nuclei
are organised into a network - mycelium


have nucleus with distinct membrane
no chloroplast(no photosynthesis) - heterotrophic 
contain cell walls (made by chitin)
store carbohydrates as glycogen 
saprotrophic nutrition
feed by secreting extracellular digestive enzymes(outside of mycelium)
absorb the digested molecules



Protoctists
unicellular or multicellular 
have nucleus with distinct membrane 
some have chloroplast - autotrophic 
some have cell walls 
store carbohydrates as glycogen 
no nervous coordination


-Prokaryotic organisms:features:
always single-celled 
do not contain a nucleus 
have nuclear material in cytoplasm in prokaryotic cells
smaller than eukaryotic cells

Bacteria
unicellular microscopic organisms
no nucleus (but contain circular DNA)
contain cell walls
no mitochondria 
no chloroplast - heterotrophic and autotrophic
store carbohydrates as glycogen or PHB

title: reasoning exercise vocabulary
content:
vocabulary list for new words I found in English reasoning exercise papers.


Week 1Daffodil(n.):a tall yellow spring shaped like a trumpet.Related vocabulary: Wales, daffodil lament, blooming.  
Obtuse(adj.):1.slow or unwilling to understand sth.2.Obtuse angle: over-180-degree anglesRelated vocabulary: smart, right angle, acute angle   
Saucepan(n.):a deep round metal pot with a lid and one long handle or two short handles.(used for cook things over heat)Related vocabulary: stewpot, pan.  
Pastry(n.):1.A mixture of flour, fat and water or milk that is rolled out flat and baked as a base or covering for pies.2.A small cake made using pastryRelated vocabulary: cake, cupcake.  
Pyramid(n.):1.A large building with a square or triangular base and a sharp top in ancient Egypt.2.A solid shape with a square or triangular base and sloping side that meet in a point at the top.3.An object or a pile of things that has the shape of a pyramid.Related vocabulary: pyramidal, Pharaoh  
Pause(n./v)1.to stop talking or doing something before continuing.2.A period of time during which sb stops talking or stops what they are doing.3.A control that allows you to stop a tape recorder, CD, etc;Related vocabulary: continue, break.  
Lukewarm(adj)1.Slightly warm;2.Not interested or enthusiasticRelated vocabulary: uninterested, chilly, lukewarmness.  
Idle(adj/v)1.Not working hard2.(of machines, factories,etc)Not in use3.Without work4.Without particular purpose or effect; useless5.Not spent doing work or sthRelated vocabulary: lazy, unemployed, idleness  
Intend(v)1.To have a plan, result or purpose in your mind when you do sth2.To plan that sth should have a particular meaning.Related vocabulary: mean, intention.   
Refuse(v,n)1.To say that you will not do sth that sb has asked you to do2.Waste materials that has been thrown awayRelated vocabulary: turn down, deny, garbage  
Nasty(adj)1.Very bad or unpleasant2.dangerous or serious3.Offensive, in bad tasteRelated vocabulary: mean, unkind, pleasant  
Concord(n)1.peace and agreement2.The fact of having the same number, gender or personRelated vocabulary: harmony, discord, agreement  
Tranquillity(n)A state of peace and quietRelated vocabulary: quiet, repose  
Serenity(n)The state of being calm, peaceful, and untroubledRelated vocabulary: serenities.  
Maim(v)To injure sb seriously, causing permanent damage to their body.Related vocabulary: disable, maimed  
Cripple(v/n)1.To damage sb’s body so that they are no longer able to walk or move normally2.To serious damage or harm ab/sth3.A person who is unable to walk or move normally because of a disease or injury.Related vocabulary: break, lameness  
Heal(v)1.To become healthy again; to make sth healthy again2.To cure sb who is ill; to make sb feel happy again3.To put an end to sth or make sth easier to bear;Related vocabulary: healing(adj), healer.  
Espy(v)To see sb/sth suddenlyRelated vocabulary: spy, spot   
Blemish(n/v)1.A mark on the skin or on an object that spoils it look less beautiful or perfect2.To spoil sth that is beautiful or perfect in all other waysRelated vocabulary: defect, soil, mud, spot  
Sting(v/n)1.To touch your skin or make a very small hole in it so that you feel a sharp pain2.To feel, or to make sb feel a sharp pain in a part of their body3.To make sb feel angry or upset.4.To charge sb more money than they expected;5.The sharp pointed part of an insect or creature that can go into the skin leaving a small, painful wound.6.Any sharp pain in your body or mind7.A clever secret plan by the police to catch criminals.8.A clever plan by criminals to cheat people out of a lot of money.Related vocabulary: stimulus, stick, pink, bite  
Chic(adj)Very fashionable and elegantRelated vocabulary: stylishness, fashion   
Dowdy(adj)1.not attractive or fashionable2.Dull or boring and not attractiveRelated vocabulary: ancient, callet.   
Toss(v)1.To throw sth lightly or carelessly2.To move your head suddenly upward, especially to show that you are annoyed or impatient.3.To move or make sb/sth move from side to side or up and down4.To shake or turn food in order to cover it with oil, butter, etc5.To throw a coin in the air in order to decide sth, especially by guessing which side is facing upward when it lands. (toss sb for sth)6.An act of throwing a coin in the air in order to decide sth7.An act of move your head suddenly upward, especially to show that you are annoyed or impatient.8.An act of throwing sth, especially in a competition or gameRelated vocabulary: cast, wap, wallow   
Fling(v,n)1.to throw sb/sth somewhere with force, especially because you are angry.2.To move yourself or part of your body suddenly and with a lot of force3.To say sth to sb in an aggressive way4.A short period of enjoyment when you do not allow yourself to worry or think seriously about anythingRelated vocabulary: put, cast, hurtle  
Bashful(adj)Shy and easily embarrassedRelated vocabulary: shy, blate  
Wary(adj)Careful when dealing with sb/sth because you think that there may be a danger or problemRelated vocabulary: cautious, prudent   
Recorder(n)1.A machine for recording sound or pictures or both.2.A musical instrument in the shape of a pipe that you blow into, with holes that you cover with your fingers.3.A person who keeps a record of events or facts.Related vocabulary: tape recorder  
Promptly(adv)1.Without delay2.Exactly at the correct time or at the time mentioned3.Immediately(always used before the verb)Related vocabulary: punctually, quickly, rapidly.   
Bail(n/v)1.money that sb agrees to pay if a person accused of a crime does not appear at their trial. When bail has been arranged, the accused person is allowed to go free until the trial.2.To release sb on bail3.To leave a place, especially quickly.4.To approach sb and talk to them, often when they do not want this.   
Week 2Squally(adj)Involving sudden, violent and strong winds(weather)Related vocabulary: showers, squall  
Sultry(adj)1.Very hot and uncomfortable2.Sexually attractive(a woman or her appearance)Related vocabulary: muggy, sexy  
Blizzard(n)1.A snowstorm with very strong winds2.A large quantity of things that may seem to be attracting you.   
Palm(n/v)1.The inner surface of the hand between the wrist and the fingers2.A straight tree with a mass of long leaves at the top, growing in the tropical countries.3.To hide a coin, card, etc. In your hand, especially when performing a trick.Related vocabulary: vola  
Decade(n)1.A period of ten years, especially a period such as 1990-1999Related vocabulary: decennium, dix  
Sleet(n/v)1.A mixture of rain and snow.2.When it is sleeting, a mixture of rain and snow is falling from the sky.Related vocabulary: verglas, sleety     
Ballad(n)1.A song or poem that tells a story2.A slow popular song about loveRelated vocabulary: derry, volkslied, balladeer   
Elect(v,sdj)1.To choose sb to do a particular job by voting for them2.To choose to do sth3.Used after nouns show that sb has been chosen for a job, but is not yet doing that job.(e.g.the president elect)4.People who have been chosen to be saved from punishment after death.Related vocabulary: remarkable, choose  
Penitent(adj/ n)1.Feeling or showing that you are sorry for having done sth wrong2.A person who shows that they are sorry for doing sth wrong, especially a religious person who wants God to forgiveRelated vocabulary: confessional, confessor, penitence  
Bill(n/v)1.A piece of paper that shows how much you owe sb for goods or services2.A piece of paper that shows how much you have to pay for the food and drinks that you had in a restaurant.3.To send sb a bill for sth4.To advertise or describe sb/sth in a particular way5.To advertise that sb/sth will do sth.Related vocabulary: statement, invoice  
Adore(v)1.To love sb very much2.To like sth very muchRelated vocabulary: love, sweetheart.   
Sage(n/adj )1.A plant with flat light green leaves that have a strong smell and are used in cooking as a herb2.A very wise person3.Wise, especially because you have a lot of experienceRelated vocabulary: herb, philosopher,   
Ponder(v)To think about sth carefully for a period of timeRelated vocabulary: consider.  
Mend(v/n)1.To repair sth that has been damaged or broken so that it can be used again2.To find a solution to a problem or disagreement3.To improve in health after being ill/sick4.To heal(of a broken bone)Related vocabulary: recover, improve, modify  
Rear(n/adj/v)1.The back part of sth2.The part of the body that you sit on3.At or near the back of sth4.To care for young children or animals until they are fully grown5.To breed or keep animals or birds, for example on a farm6.To raise itself on its back legs, with the front legs in the air7.To seem to lean over you, especially in a threatening way(sth large)Related vocabulary: raise, back, aback, set  
Week 3Sombre(adj)1.dark in colour, dull2.Sad and seriousRelated vocabulary: drab, melancholy, upset, dark  
Daybreak(n)The time of day when light first appearsRelated vocabulary: dawn   
Govern( adj )1.To legally control a country or its people and be responsible for introducing new laws, organizing public services, etc2.To control or influence sb/sth or how sth happens, function, etc3.If a word governs another word or phrase, it affects how that word or phrase is formed or used.Related vocabulary: manage, possess, conduct, regulate.  
Timid(adj)Shy and nervous; not braveRelated vocabulary: modest, harehearted   
Brisk(adj)1.Quick, busy2.Practical and confident; showing a desire to get things done quickly3.Cold but pleasantly freshRelated vocabulary: alive, acute, keen, lively, activated   
Bold(adj)1.Brave and confident, not afraid to say what you feel or to take risks2.That can be easily seen; having a strong clear appearanceRelated vocabulary: rapid , stouthearted   
Operate(v)1.To work in a particular way2.To be used or working; to use sth or make it work3.to cut open sb’s body in order to remove a part that has a disease or to repair a part that is damaged4.To be involved in military activities in a placeRelated vocabulary: act, handle, operation  
Counterfeit(adj/v)1.Made to look exactly like sth in order to trick people into thinking that they are getting the real thing2.To make an exact copy of sth in order to trick people into thinking that it is the real thingRelated vocabulary: fake, simulate, shoddy, counterfeiter  
Immerse(v)1.To put sb/sth into a liquid so that they or it are completely covered2.To become or make sb completely involved in sthRelated vocabulary: entrap   
Contort(v)To become twisted or make sth twisted out of its natural or normal shapeRelated vocabulary: distort\  
Panorama(n)1.a view of a wide area of land2.A description, study or set of pictures that presents all the different aspects or stages of a particular subject, event, etcRelated vocabulary: panoramic, panoptic   
Conceit(n)1.Too much pride in yourself and what you do2.An artistic effect or device, especially one that is very clever or tries to be very clever but does not succeed3.A clever expression in writing or speech that involves a comparison between two thingsRelated vocabulary: ego, fantasize   
Week 4Overcast(adj ):Covered with clouds;dullRelated vocabulary: cloudy, dull,shadow, shield   
Kindle(v)1.To start burning; to make a fire start burning2.To make sth such as an interest, emotion, etc. Start to grow in sb; to start to be felt by sbRelated vocabulary: lamp, emblaze  
Potent(adj)1.Having a strong effect on your body or mind2.PowerfulRelated vocabulary: valid, effective, virtual  
Scrub(v/n)1.To clean sth by rubbing it hard, perhaps with a brush and usually with soap and water2.To cancel sth that you have arranged to do3.An act of scrubbing4.Small bushes and trees5.The special clothes worn by surgeons when they are doing medical operationsRelated vocabulary: small, scouring, depurate  
Anticipate(v)1.To expect sth2.To see what might happen in the future and take action to prepare for it3.To think with pleasure and excitement about sth that is going to happen4.To do sth before it an be done by sb elseRelated vocabulary: hope, expect  
Gossip(n/v)1.Informal talk or stories about other people’s private lives, that may be unkind or not true2.A conversation about other people3.A person who enjoys talking about other people’s private livesRelated vocabulary: essay, quidnunc   
Impede(v)To delay or stop the process of sthRelated vocabulary: hinder, hamper  
Agile(adj)1.Able to move quickly and easily2.Able to think quickly and in an intelligent wayRelated vocabulary: nimble, fly, sharp , keen   
Enclosure(n)1.A piece of land that is surrounded by a fence or wall and is used for a particular purpose2.The act of placing a fence or wall around a piece of land3.Something that is placed in an envelope with a letterRelated vocabulary: attachment, pen   
Week 5Apparel(u):1.Clothing, when it is being sold in shops/stores2.Clothes, particularly those worn on a formal occasionRelated vocabulary: clothing, garment, array, wear.  
Bleach(v/n):  

to make sth white or pale by a chemical process or by the effect of light from the sun; to become white or pale in this way3.A chemical that is used to make sth become white or pale and as a disinfectant.Related vocabulary: snow, whiten, decolorant, whitener.

Emerge(v)1.To come out of a dark, confined or hidden place2.To become known3.To start to exist; to appear or become known4.To survive a difficult situation or experienceRelated vocabulary: appear.  
Blend(v/n)1.To mix two or more substances together2.To form a mixture with sth3.To combine with sth in an attractive or effective way; to combine sth in this way4.To produce sth by mixing different types together5.A mixture of different types of the same thing6.A pleasant or useful combination of different things(a blend of youth and experience 年轻而且有经验)Related vocabulary: compound, mixture, sort  
Week 6Solitary(adj/n)1.Done alone; without other people2.Enjoying being alone; frequently spending time alone3.Alone with no other people or things around4.Only one(in negative sentences and questions)Related vocabulary: alone, neighborless, hermit, anchorite, solitarily, solitude, solitariness   
Plaice 比目鱼   
Hake  鳕鱼     
Sole 可食用比目鱼 
Lamb(n/v)1.A young sheep2.Meat from a young sheep3.Used to describe or address sb with affection or pity4.To give birth to a lambRelated vocabulary: kidlet, yeanling, lamblike   
Veal(n)Meat from a calf(a young cow)Related vocabulary: calf, runt  
Foe(n)An enemyRelated vocabulary: enemy, anti, opponent  
Adversary(n)A person that sb is opposed to and competing with in and argument or a battleRelated vocabulary: equal, opponent, comparative, rival, match  
Novel(n/adj)1.A story long enough to fill a complete book,in which the characters and events are usually imaginary2.Different from anything known before; new, interesting and often seeming slightly strangeRelated vocabulary: patent, exquisite, story, fiction   
burst in on sb/sth:to interrupt sb/sth by entering a place suddenly and noisilyRelated: barge  
Pallid(adj)1.Pale, especially because of illness2.Not strong or bright, and therefore not attractiveRelated vocabulary: gray, dirty, pale, wan  
Faint(adj/v/n)1.That cannot be clearly seen, heard or smelt2.Very small; possible but unlikely3.Not enthusiastic4.Feeling weak and tired and likely to become unconscious5.To become unconscious when not enough blood is going to your brain, usually because of the heat, a shock, etc.6.The state of becoming unconsciousRelated vocabulary: fuzzy, weak, dark, black out.   
Conceal(v)To hide sb/sthRelated vocabulary: lock, pocket, to hide  
Week 7Lettuce(n)A plant with large green leaves that are eaten raw, especially in salad. There are many types of lettuceRelated vocabulary: william, banknote   
Effortless(adj)Needing little or no effort, so that it seems easyRelated vocabulary: easy, light, easiest  
Diverse(adj)Very different from each other and of various kindsDifferent, unlike, varying, another, dissimilar  
Curtail(v)To limit sth or make it last for a shorter timeRelated vocabulary: crop, to cut back   
Stretch(v/n)1.To make sth longer, wider or looser, for example by pulling it; to become longer, etc. In this way2.To become bigger or longer when you pull it and return to its original shape when you stop3.To pull sth so that it is smooth and tight4.To put you arms or legs out straight and contract you muscles5.To put out an arm or a leg in order to reach sth6.To spread over an area of land7.To continue over a period of time8.To be enough to buy or pay for sth9.To make use of a lot of your money, supplies, time, etc.10.To make use of all sb’s skill, intelligence, etc.11.To use sth in a way that would not normally be considered fair, acceptable, etc12.An area of land or water, especially a long one13.A continuous period of time14.A period of time that sb spends in prison15.An act of stretching out your arms or legs or your body and contracting the muscles; the state of being stretched16.The ability to be made longer or wider without breaking or tearing17.A straight part at the end of a racing trackRelated vocabulary: lengthen  
Tardy(adj)Slow to act, move or happen; late in happening or arrivingRelated vocabulary: slow-motion, overdue, late for, late arrival.   
Punctual(adj)Happening or doing sth at the arranged or correct time, not lateRelated vocabulary: accurate, precise, mathematical, strict, rigid   
Cradle(n/v)1.A small bed for a baby which can be pushed gently from side to side2.The place where sth important began3.A small platform that can be moved up and down the outside of a high building, used by people cleaning windows, etc4.The part of a telephone on which the receiver rests5.To hold sb/sth gently in your arms or handsRelated vocabulary: cot, bassinet, foster   
Crib(n/v)1.=cot, cradle2.A long open box that horses and cows can eat from3.Written information such as an answer to questions, often used dishonestly by students in tests4.The house, flat/apartment, etc.5.To dishonestly copy work from another student or from a bookRelated vocabulary: cot, cradle, copy, plagiarize   
Hamper(n/v)1.To prevent sb from easily doing or achieving sth2.A large basket with a lid, a box or package containing food, sent as a gift3.A large basket that you keep your dirty clothes in until they are washedRelated vocabulary: let, chain, hinder, slow down, hindrance, basket, punnet   
Bazaar(n)1.(in some Eastern countries)A street or an area of a town where there are many small shops2.(in british, the US, etc) a sale of goods, often items made by hand, to raise money for a charityRelated vocabulary: exchanges, mart, plaza   
Nasty(adj)1.Very bad or unpleasant2.Unkind; unpleasant3.Dangerous or serious4.Offensive; in bad tasteRelated vocabulary: blue, dirty   
Crown(n/v)1.An object in the shape of a circle, usually made of gold and precious stones, that a king or queen wears on his or her head on official occasions2.The highest part of sth3.to put a crown on the head of a new king or queen as a sign of royal power4.To form or cover the top of sth5.To hit sb on the headRelated vocabulary: height, summit, peak, coronate, cite

title: Paper 1 section B -writing a response
content:
Revision note for CIE English Lit Paper 1 section B.
Including terms and answering strategies.


Section Bpreparing responseread questions:Choose 1 question from 2 question choices 

question 1
giving a passage from a text


question 2
no passage, whole text



time management


time spend
task



10 min
- decide question- highlight keywords on the question- annotate keywords and phrases- make brief plan of answering structure


30 min
- follow the plan and annotations- write response


5 min
- re-read and check answers


responses tips
highlight keywords in the questions 
use quotations to support the idea, themselves should not be a point of view 
respond to every section of the poem 
last stanza:
where poet emphasises their message or attitude


give reasons for the explanation and annotations 
because, as, since


link to the questions 
embed the quotations into the sentence 
this is shown by quote …


avoid narratives
include annotation of structure and form 
conclusion of response:
personal response on the poem and questions 
give new point of views



analyze proseterms
foreshadowing 
a warning or a prediction of a future event in the story 
Or employ dramatic irony 
readers are aware of what is coming 
characters are not




flashbacks 
a scene set in a time earlier than the main story 
be used to convey extra information about plot or character


soliloquies 
a speech which a character makes to themselves 
showing a character’s inner thoughts


dialogue
conversation between two or more characters



perspectives
first-person narrator 
story is told from the perspective of a character
identified by the use of “I” 
make readers feel sympathy for the character
Or exposing the character as an unreliable narrator 
dramatic irony 
the readers know something the narrator does not know




third-person narrator 
story is told from the perspective that sits outside of the world of the story 
omniscient narrator:
the narrator knows everything about the characters and events





writing responseintroduction
use the wording of the question to develop an introduction in your own words

main paragraphs
start with a topic sentence 
use quotations and references to prove the point 
explain how the evidence proves the point

question 1 strategies (passage)
detailed analysis of the passage 
link to the question 
comment on how the passage relates to the whole text

question 2 strategies (whole text)
discuss the structure and perspectives of the novel, linking to the question 
zoom in on particular parts of the prose which are directly relevant to the question

conclusion / summarysummarize findings and responsegive new point of views(no repetition of the idea)

title: Paper 1 section A -writing a response
content:
Revision note for CIE English Lit Paper 1 section A.
Including structure and language techniques and answering tips.


Section Aanswering tipstime management


time spend
task



10 min
- decide question- highlight keywords on the question- re-read the poem- annotate- make brief plan of answering structure


30 min
- follow the plan and annotations- write response


5 min
- re-read and check answers


Key words
explore: write in detail 
how: examine techniques the writer has used to achieve a specific effect 
vividly / convey: produce powerful feelings and strong clear images in mind 
how far / to what extent: an element of the text allowing to make a counter-argument
portray: explore how writer describe or bring a character or a theme to life in text. 
memorable: how writer presents a character of event in a way that stands out  / worth remembering

responses tips
highlight keywords in the questions 
use quotations to support the idea, themselves should not be a point of view 
respond to every section of the poem 
last stanza:
where poet emphasises their message or attitude


give reasons for the explanation and annotations 
because, as, since


link to the questions 
embed the quotations into the sentence 
this is shown by quote …


avoid narratives
include annotation of structure and form 
conclusion of response:
personal response on the poem and questions 
give new point of views



structure and forms of poemsForms / genre
sonnet 
14 lines 
usually theme of love 
petrarchan sonnet(Italian)
ABBA, ABBA, CDE, CDE rhyme scheme


shakespearean sonnet(English)
ABAB, CDCD, EFEF, GG rhyme scheme




epic 
ancient 
lengthy narrative poem 
typically heroic deeds


free verse 
a lack of rules 
can rhyme or not 
about any themes


villanelle
19 lines
five stanza of 3 lines 
final stanza of 4 lines 
only 2 rhyming sounds(ABA)


ode 
originally performed with musical instruments
praise a person, event or thing 
short in length


ballad 
telling dramatic or emotional story 
ABAB or ABCB rhyme scheme
poets may alter the rhyme scheme, subverting a traditional form to convey an idea





structure


techniques
explanation



stanza length
changes on the length of lines


repetition
repetition of words, phrase or ideas


caesura
using punctuations at the mid of a line


enjambment
a lack of punctuation at the end of a line


shift
change in ideas and perspectives


contrast
difference between two things


pace
the feeling of speed in the writing


temporal references
references to time


dialogue
conversations and speech


LanguageTerms of language
comparative adjectives 
used to compare difference between 2 nouns 
e.g. larger, smaller, faster


superlatives
used to express something of the highest quality of its kind 
e.g. fairest, prettiest, funest


emotive language
words and phrases that are used to evoke strong emotional responses in the reader


colloquial language 
informal, everyday language


imperatives 
verb forms or sentences that are used to give commands 
e.g. “Fill your belly”, “Day and night make merry”



language techniques
simile
directly compare two different things 
use “like”,”as”


metaphor
describe one thing in terms of another 
indirectly compare


imagery 
engage the readers senses by using vivid and detailed language to create mental image


alliteration 
repetition of consonant sounds 
e.g. beech buggy


personification
give objects human characteristics or movements


onomatopoeia 
words that imitate or mimic the sounds


repetition 
repeat of words, phrases, sounds or structure to create emphasis


juxtaposition 
contrast 
place two contrasting things side by side to highlight the differences


assonance 
repetition of vowel sounds 
sounds similar 
e.g. moonlit pool, cock of the walk


rule of three 
list of 3 things or ideas 
e.g. freedom, equality and justice


rhetorical questions 
a question asked for effect with no answer expected


emotive language
words or phrases that can bring an emotional response


hyperbole
exaggeration for effect

title: Circulatory system/cardiovascular system
content:
Revision note for Edexcel IGCSE Biology.
discussing circulatory system, including blood, vessels and heart. 


Bloodplasma
pale yellow liquid 
carrying everything that needs transporting around hunan body:
blood cells:
red blood cell
white blood cell
platelets 
digested food products - from gut to all body cells 
carbon dioxide 
urea - from liver to the kidneys (be removed in the urine)
hormones
heat energy





platelets
small fragments of cells 
help blood clotting 
stop body losing too much blood 
prevent microorganisms from entering the wound 
In a clot:
platelets are held together by a protein called fibrin
other proteins call clotting factors are needed to work properly in this process





red blood cell
carry and transport oxygen from the lung to all the cells in the body 
adaptational features:
small with a biconcave shape
larger surface area for absorbing and releasing oxygen.


contain haemoglobin 
contain iron - gives blood its colour 
reacts with oxygen to become oxyhaemoglobin
reverse reaction happens to release oxygen to the cells


no nucleus
more space for more haemoglobin 
carry more oxygen





White blood cells
most important part of immune system
phagocytes
ingest pathogens


lymphocytes 
produce antibodies




more white blood cells’ information in immune system part. 


VesselsArteries branch into capillaries, and capillaries eventually join upp to form veins 
Arteries
features:
carry the blood away from the heart 
carry oxygenated blood (except the pulmonary artery)
transport blood in high pressure 
transport blood in fast speed 
thick muscular walls 
contain elastic fibres


narrow lumen


adaptational features:
thick muscular walls containing elastic fibres 
withstand high pressure of blood 
maintain high pressure of blood


narrow lumen 
maintain high pressure




aorta - largest artery in the body

Veins
features:
carry blood toward the heat 
carry deoxygenated blood (except pulmonary vein)
transport blood in low pressure 
transport blood in slow speed 
thin walls 
large lumen
contain valves


adaptational features:
large lumen:
reduce resistance to blood flow under low pressure


valves:
prevent the backflow of blood




vena cava - largest vein in the body

Capillaries
features:
very tiny 
carry both oxygenated and deoxygenated blood 
transport blood in low pressure 
transport blood in slow speed 
thin walls
one cell thick


carry blood very close to every cell
exchange substances with cells


supply food and oxygen
take away wastes (e.g. CO_2)


adaptational features:
one-cell-thick walls
decrease diffusion distance 
increase rate of diffusion


permeable walls 
substances are easy to diffuse in and out






Heart
cardiac: heart 

structureleft atrium
connected with pulmonary vein 
receive oxygenated blood from lungs

left ventricle
connected to aorta 
pumped out oxygenated blood around the body 
adaptational features:
thick wall - more muscles 
higher pressure 
pump blood around the whole body - long distance





right atrium
connected to vana cava 
receive deoxygenated blood from the body

right ventricle
connected to pulmonary artery 
pumped out deoxygenated blood to the lungs

Valves
preventing blood flowing backwards
in main vessels: 
semi-lunar valve 
pulmonary artery
aorta




inside heart:
bicuspid valve == left atrium $\longrightarrow$ left ventricle 
tricuspid valve == right atrium $\longrightarrow$ right ventricle




coronary heart disease (CHD)
coronary arteries:
blood vessels supplying blood(oxygen,glucose) to the heart muscle (cardiac muscle)


coronary arteries get blocked by layers of fatty material building up 
formed from cholesterol 
two source of cholesterol 
dietary cholesterol (from eaten animal products)
cholesterol synthesised by the liver




angina
partial blockage 
restricted blood flow to the cardiac muscle cells 
severe chest pains


heart attack 
complete blockage 
lack of oxygen 
heart cells can not respire aerobically



risk factors:
diet high in saturated fat
fatty deposits inside arteries


smoking 
increases blood pressure 
cause damage to the inside of the coronary arteries 
fatty deposits inside arteries 
carbon monoxide will decrease the oxygen capacity of red blood cells 





circulatory systemlesser circuit (circuit through lung)
deoxygenated blood flow through vena cava into the right atrium
right atrium contracts and blood flows through tricuspid valve into right ventricle 
right ventricle contracts and blood flows through the semilunar valve in the pulmonary artery 
blood flows through the pulmonary artery into the lungs, through the capillaries around alveoli 
gas exchange - deoxygenated blood $\longrightarrow$ oxygenated blood 
oxygenated blood flows back through teh pulmonary vein into the left atrium


vena cava $\longrightarrow$ right atrium $\longrightarrow$ right ventricle $\longrightarrow$ pulmonary artery $\longrightarrow$ lungs $\longrightarrow$ pulmonary vein $\longrightarrow$ left atrium $\longrightarrow$ left ventriclevalves: tricuspid valve / semilunar valve

greater circuit (circuit through the whole body)
left atrium $\longrightarrow$ left ventricle through bicuspid valve 
left ventricle $\longrightarrow$ aorta, through the semi-lunar valve 
aorta $\longrightarrow$ rest of body 
aorta $\longrightarrow$ brain $\longrightarrow$ brain vein $\longrightarrow$ vena cava 
aorta $\longrightarrow$ hepatic artery $\longrightarrow$ liver $\longrightarrow$ hepatic vein $\longrightarrow$ vena cava 
aorta $\longrightarrow$ mesenteric artery $\longrightarrow$ gut $\longrightarrow$ hepatic portal vein $\longrightarrow$ liver $\longrightarrow$ hepatic vein $\longrightarrow$ vena cava 
aorta $\longrightarrow$ renal artery $\longrightarrow$ kidney $\longrightarrow$ renal vein $\longrightarrow$ vena cava






Organ
vessels in
vessels out



Heart
Vena cava
pulmonary vein


Lung
pulmonary artery
pulmonary vein


kidney
renal artery
renal vain


gut
mesenteric artery
hepatic portal vein



heart rateHeart rate :measured by counting the number of times a heart beats in a minute (bpm)
Pacemaker: 

a group of cells in teh right atrium 
coordinate the contraction of heart muscle
by sending electrical impulses which initiate a contraction in the cardiac muscle


control the natural resting heart rate


Heart when exercising
heart pumps blood to cells:
supply oxygen and glucose 
remove respiratory waste


factors:
exercise 
adrenaline level


during exercise:
heart rate increase $\longrightarrow$ more frequent
volume of blood increase $\longrightarrow$ larger volume


after exercise:
heart rate remain high for a period of time  
to break down lactic acid from anaerobic respiration (oxygen required)
moderate exercise -mainly aerobic respirationintense exercise -mainly anaerobic respiration
